title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates a criminal background check for child care staff, family child care providers, and adults living in the home of a family child care provider in states receiving funds under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The check includes searches of the National Sex Offender Registry, National Crime Information Center, and State criminal registry. The Protection and Safety Act of 2006 requires background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state criminal registries, abuse and neglect databases, and FBI fingerprint checks. The Protection and Safety Act of 2006 mandates background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state criminal registries, abuse and neglect databases, and FBI fingerprint checks. Child care providers are ineligible for funds if a criminal background check reveals an adult felony conviction for child abuse or neglect, spousal abuse, crimes against children, or violent crimes. Child care providers must undergo background checks, including searches of criminal registries and FBI fingerprint checks. They are ineligible for funds if convicted of adult felonies related to child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, or violent crimes. Child care providers must undergo background checks, including criminal registries and FBI fingerprint checks. They are ineligible for funds if convicted of felonies related to child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, or violent crimes committed within 5 years prior to the background check submission. Providers must request a State and national criminal background check through the designated State agency for staff members or residents in their private residence. Child care staff members and providers must undergo background checks, including criminal registries and FBI fingerprint checks. They must comply with requirements every 5 years, and prospective staff members or providers must also undergo background checks. Child care staff members, family providers, and adults must undergo background checks every 5 years. Prospective staff members or providers also need background checks before starting their roles. Child care staff members, family providers, and adults must undergo background checks every 5 years. Only one request is needed for a State and national criminal background check for each individual residing in the provider's private residence during a 5-year period. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request. Child care providers and individuals in private residences must undergo background checks every 5 years. Results of the criminal background check must be provided within 10 business days of the request. A copy of the background check can be requested by the individual or entity. Child care providers and individuals in private residences must undergo background checks every 5 years. Results of the criminal background check must be provided within 10 business days of the request. A State shall provide a copy of the background check upon request. The State must ensure accuracy by obtaining dispositions of arrests, correcting inaccurate information, and completing incomplete entries. Child care providers and individuals in private residences must undergo background checks every 5 years. Results of the criminal background check must be provided within 10 business days of the request. A State shall ensure accuracy by obtaining dispositions of arrests, correcting inaccurate information, and completing incomplete entries. Appeals can be made to the appropriate State agency within 30 days of receiving the background check results. Child care providers and individuals subject to background checks can appeal the results to the State agency within 30 days. The State must determine eligibility, provide specific findings, and correct any inaccurate or incomplete information in the individual's criminal record promptly. Child care providers or family child care providers can appeal background check results to the State agency within 30 days. The State must provide specific findings, make necessary changes to the individual's criminal record, and report these changes to the individual. States can collect a fee not exceeding $36 per criminal background check to cover administration costs. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 allows child care providers to appeal background check results within 30 days. States can charge a fee of up to $36 per criminal background check to cover administration costs. States must implement these requirements within 3 years of the Act's enactment, with a possible 2-year extension granted by the Secretary for good faith efforts. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 allows states to grant a 2-year extension for compliance with background check requirements. Definitions in the Act include 'adult' as a person over 18 years old and 'child care provider' as a licensed provider of child care services. Child care staff members are individuals who provide child care services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding those related to the children they care for. Family child care providers are defined separately in the Act. Child care staff members provide services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding those related to the children they care for. Family child care providers offer services for fewer than 24 hours per day in a private residence, are not related to all children in their care, and are licensed, regulated, or registered under State law. Child care staff members provide services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding those related to the children they care for. Family child care providers offer services in a private residence, are not related to all children in their care, and are licensed, regulated, or registered under State law. Authorization of appropriations is provided for conducting criminal background checks.
